mt0: <pad> As a member of the Islamic State who left his country of Morocco to join what he thought was a holy war in Syria, Mohsin said he saw all the atrocities of the war.</s>

en: A terrifying experience, he says.
xho: Amava awoyikisayo, utsho njalo.
mt0: <pad> The dreaded storms, he says.</s>

en: Now a prisoner, the 38-year-old claims he is no longer the fanatic he was then, enraged with a murderous hatred for non-Muslims.
xho: Ngoku elibanjwa, elineminyaka engama-38 ubudala libanga ukuba akasenguye laa mntu wayenenzodelelo yempambano ngelo xesha, enomsindo wokubulala abantu abangengawo amaSilamsi.
mt0: <pad> Now the 38-year-old prisoner, who is now in jail, says he was not the person who had the motive for the attack at the time, when he was angry with the killing of non-Muslims.</s>

en: Captured in Turkey and extradited to Morocco, he is serving a 10-year prison term on terrorism charges.
xho: Ubanjelwe eTurkey waza wathunyelwa eMorocco, uthothoza iminyaka elishumi entolongweni ngezityholo zobunqolobi.
mt0: <pad> He was arrested in Turkey and sent to Morocco, where he is facing 10 years in jail on terror charges.</s>

en: Now the former fighter has graduated with 14 other prisoners convicted of terror offenses from a Morocco de-radicalization program that might make them more eligible for an early release.
xho: Ngoku lo wayesakuba ngumlwi uphumelele kunye namanye amabanjwa ali-14 agwetywe kulwaphulo-mthetho lwenkqubo yase-Morocco yotshintsho enokuthi ibenze bafaneleke ngakumbi ukukhululwa phambi kwexesha.
mt0: <pad> Now the former soldier has succeeded with 14 other prisoners convicted of crimes under the Morocco reform process which could make them more eligible for early release.</s>

en: The Associated Press and other media were invited to observe their graduation ceremony Thursday in a prison in Sale near the Moroccan capital, Rabat.
xho: I-Associated Press kunye namanye amajelo eendaba amenyiwe ukuba abukele umsitho wabo wokuphumelela ngoLwesine kwintolongo eseSale kufutshane nekomkhulu laseMorocco, iRabat.
mt0: <pad> The Associated Press and other media were invited to attend their victory party on Thursday in Sale prison near the Moroccan capital, Rabat.</s>

en: And to interview some prisoners under monitored and controlled conditions. Prison administration officials picked out three men they said were willing to be interviewed.
xho: Kwaye enze udliwano-ndlebe namanye amabanjwa phantsi kweemeko ezibekwe esweni nezilawulwayo. Amagosa olawulo lwentolongo akhetha amadoda amathathu athi akulungele ukuba nodliwano-ndlebe.
mt0: <pad> He interviewed other inmates under supervised and controlled conditions. The prison administration selected three men who said they were not ready for an interview.</s>

en: Officials stipulated that the inmates shouldn't be identified by their full names and that their faces mustn't be shown, citing privacy reasons.
xho: Amagosa amisela ukuba amabanjwa akufunekanga achazwe ngamagama awo apheleleyo kwaye ubuso bawo bungaboniswa, echaza izizathu zokufihlwa kwabo.
mt0: <pad> The authorities decided that the inmates should not be identified by their full names and faces, describing the reasons for their hiding.</s>

en: But prison officials didn't listen to the interviews or intervene to shut down media lines of questioning or inmates' answers.
xho: Kodwa amagosa entolongo akazange amamele udliwano-ndlebe okanye angenelele ukuvala imigca yemithombo yeendaba yemibuzo okanye iimpendulo zamabanjwa.
mt0: <pad> But prison officials did not listen to the interview or intervene to close media channels for questions or answers from inmates.</s>

en: The 15 inmates in crisp shirts and trousers stood solemnly for Morocco's national anthem and were handed certificates.
xho: Amabanjwa ali-15 anxibe iihempe neebhulukhwe ema ngokundilisekileyo ephulaphule umhobe wesizwe waseMorocco kwaye anikwa iziqinisekiso.
mt0: <pad> The 15 prisoners dressed in hijabs and trousers stood with pride as they listened to the national anthem of Morocco and were given certificates.</s>

en: Prison officials said the de-radicalization program consisted of three months of classes in prison on religion, law and economics, and that inmates also received training on how to start a business.
xho: Amagosa entolongo athi inkqubo yotshintsho yayibandakanya iinyanga ezintathu zokufundiswa ngonqulo entolongweni, umthetho nezoqoqosho, kwaye amabanjwa nawo afumana uqeqesho ngendlela yokuqalisa ishishini.
mt0: <pad> The prison officials said the change program included three months of in-prison religious education, law and economics, and the inmates also received training on how to start a business.</s>

en: These most recent graduates were the ninth batch since the program started in 2017.
xho: Aba basanda kuphumelela bebeyibhetshi yethoba ukusukela oko yaqala inkqubo ngo-2017.
mt0: <pad> The recent winners were the eighth batch since the program began in 2017.</s>

en: Moulay Idriss Agoulmam, the director of social-cultural action and prisoner reintegration at Morocco's prison administration, said the program is entirely voluntary and works with inmates "to change their behavior and improve their life path."
xho: UMoulay Idriss Agoulmam, umlawuli weSocial-Cultural Action and Prisoner Reintergration kwintolongo yaseMorocco, uthe le nkqubo yeyabo bafunayo kwaye isebenza namabanjwa "ukutshintsha indlela yokuziphatha kunye nokuphucula indlela yabo yokuphila."
mt0: <pad> Moula Idriss Agoulmam, director of Social-Cultural Action and Prisoner Reintegration in the Moroccan jail, said the program is for the prisoners and works with them "to change behavior and improve their quality of life."</s>

en: It enables prisoners to form an awareness of the gravity of their mistakes, he said.
xho: “Ivumela amabanjwa ukuba aqonde ubunzulu beempazamo zawo,” utshilo.
mt0: <pad> "It allows inmates to understand the magnitude of their mistakes," he said.</s>

en: Graduating from the program doesn't make inmates automatically eligible for early release, but does increase their chances of getting a royal pardon or a reduced sentence.
xho: Ukuthweswa isidanga kule nkqubo akuwenzi amabanjwa afanelekele ukukhululwa kwangoko, kodwa konyusa amathuba awo okufumana uxolelo lwasebukhosini okanye isigwebo esincitshisiweyo.
mt0: <pad> The conviction in this program does not make the inmates eligible for early release, but it increases their chances of getting royal pardon or a shortened sentence.</s>

en: That's been the case for just over half the program's 222 graduates so far, the prison administration says.
xho: Kube njalo ngaphezu kwesiqingatha sabafundi abaphumeleleyo abangama-222 ukuza kuthi ga ngoku, utshilo abaphathi bentolongo.
mt0: <pad> Over half of the 222 graduates have been released so far, prison officials said.</s>

en: Diversity, New Perspectives Are Applied to Middle East Coverage
xho: Iyantlukwano, iimbono ezitsha ziyasetyenziswa kuMbindi Mpuma
mt0: <pad> Differences, new ideas are used in the Middle East.</s>

en: Natalia Sancha has always adopted a collaborative approach to journalism.
xho: U-Natalia Sancha ebesoloko esamkela indlela yokusebenzisana kubuntatheli.
mt0: <pad> Natalia Sancha has always been open to the idea of co-operation in journalistic work.</s>

en: When out on assignment, she speaks to others covering the same story about their perspectives.
xho: Xa eyokwenza umsebenzi wakhe ngaphandle, uthetha nabanye abagubungela ibali elifanayo ngeembono zabo.
mt0: <pad> When he goes to do his work outside, he speaks with other journalists who cover the same story about their opinions.</s>

en: This partly stems from an interest in telling underreported stories, but as a female journalist in a male-dominated region, she says collaboration and supporting the women she works with have always been important.
xho: Oku ngokuyinxenye kuvela kumdla wokubalisa amabali angabaliswayo ngokwaneleyo, kodwa njengentatheli yasethyini kwindawo elawulwa ngamadoda, uthi intsebenziswano kunye nokuxhasa amanina asebenza nawo ibisoloko ibalulekile.
mt0: <pad> This is partly due to the interest in telling stories that are not enough told, but as a feminist journalist in a male-dominated environment, she says cooperation and support for women colleagues has always been important.</s>

en: I would talk to male and female journalists, and I always realized that women had a similar perspective, because we had similar experiences while covering the story, the 42-year-old journalist said.
xho: “Bendikhe ndithethe neentatheli zamadoda nabasetyhini, kwaye bendisoloko ndiqaphela ukuba abasetyhini banembono efanayo, kuba nathi besinamava afanayo ngelixa sibhala eli bali,” yatsho intatheli eneminyaka engama-42 ubudala.
mt0: <pad> "I've talked to men and women journalists, and I've always noticed that women have the same opinion, because we had the same experience when we were writing this story," said the 42-year-old journalist.</s>

en: That collaborative approach came into play in 2020 when a publisher asked Sancha if she was interested in writing a book about Syria.
xho: Le ndlela yokusebenzisana yaqala ukusebenza ngo-2020 xa umvakalisi wabuza uSancha ukuba unomdla wokubhala incwadi ngeSyria.
mt0: <pad> This collaboration began in 2020 when a reporter asked Sancha if he was interested in writing a book about Syria.</s>

en: She countered with a better offer.
xho: Wachasa enombono olungcono.
mt0: <pad> You're a better photographer</s>

en: I told him that a collective narrative by women journalists about the broader region would have a different effect, she said.
xho: “Ndimxelele ukuba ibali elidityanelweyo leentatheli zabasetyhini malunga nommandla obanzi lingaba nefuthe elahlukileyo,” utshilo.
mt0: <pad> "I told her that a story by women journalists about the wider region could have a different impact," she said.</s>

en: I could have written the book myself, but it would not have the same sense.
xho: Ngendiyibhale ngokwam le ncwadi, kodwa ayinakuba nengqiqo efanayo.
mt0: <pad> I could have written this book myself, but it wouldn't have the same meaning.</s>

en: Originally from Andalusia in southern Spain, Sancha spent the past 14 years in the Middle East covering conflicts in Iraq, Syria and Yemen, and reporting from Egypt, Lebanon and Tunisia.
xho: Onemvelaphi yaseAndalusia kumazantsi eSpain, uSancha uchithe iminyaka eli-14 edlulileyo kuMbindi Mpuma egubungela ungquzulwano eIraq, eSyria naseYemen, kwaye enika ingxelo eseEgypt, eLebhanon naseTunisia.
mt0: <pad> From Andalusia in southern Spain, Sancha has spent the last 14 years in the Middle East covering conflicts in Iraq, Syria and Yemen, and reporting on Egypt, Lebanon and Tunisia.</s>

en: She has been working more recently with the European Union communications department, after leaving Beirut for health reasons following a mass explosion that rocked the city in 2020.
xho: Usebenze kutsha nje nesebe lezonxibelelwano le-European Union, emva kokushiya i-Beirut ngenxa yezizathu zempilo kulandela ugqabhuko-dubulo olukhulu olwanyakamisa isixeko ngo-2020.
mt0: <pad> He has recently worked with the European Union's communication department, after leaving Beirut for medical reasons following the large explosion that rocked the city in 2020.</s>

en: Women "have a different experience because we would go to places that our male colleagues were not used to.
xho: Abasetyhini “banamava ahlukileyo kuba besisiya kwiindawo abangaziqhelanga oogxa bethu abangamadoda.
mt0: <pad> Women "had a different experience because we were going to places our male colleagues were not familiar with."</s>

en: Not because we're smarter, but just because the majority of the region is still Arab, Muslim and gender-segregated," Sancha told VOA.
xho: Hay ngenxa yokuba sihlakaniphile, kodwa ngenxa yokuba uninzi lwalo mmandla lusengama-Arabhu, amaSilamsi kunye nolwahlulo ngokwesini, "uSancha uxelele iVOA.
mt0: <pad> "Not because we are smart, but because the majority of the region is Arab, Muslim and gender bias," Sancha told the VOA.</s>

en: Having women reporters has an impact, she noted.
xho: Ukuba neentatheli zabasetyhini kunempembelelo, waphawula.
mt0: <pad> Being with women journalists has an impact, she said.</s>

en: If I put myself in the position of the reader, I would prefer to have a woman telling me the story because it is going to be about 100 percent of the population, which means you are going to have a more inclusive narrative on the conflict.
xho: Ukuba ndizibeka kwindawo yomfundi, ndingathanda ukuba nomntu wasetyhini ondixelela ibali kuba liza kuba malunga ne-100 yepesenti yabemi, oku kuthetha ukuba uya kuba nengxelo ebandakanya ngakumbi kwingxabano. .
mt0: <pad> If I were a student, I'd like to have a woman tell me the story because she will be about 100 percent of the population, which means she will have a more involved report in the conflict.</s>

en: For her book, Sancha reached out to other women who cover the Middle East, to ensure diverse perspectives from foreign and local reporters.
xho: Kwincwadi yakhe, u-Sancha wafikelela kwabanye abafazi abagubungela uMbindi Mpuma, ukuqinisekisa iimbono ezahlukeneyo ezivela kwiintatheli zangaphandle kunye nezasekhaya.
mt0: <pad> In her book, Sancha reached out to other women journalists who cover the Middle East, to verify different perspectives from both foreign and domestic journalists.</s>

en: The result of the nearly two-year collaboration is Bullets for All, released in Spanish in April.
xho: Isiphumo sentsebenziswano ephantse ibe yiminyaka emibini yiBullets for All, ekhutshwe ngeSpanish ngoAprili.
mt0: <pad> The result of a two-year collaboration is Bullets for All, published in Spanish in April.</s>

en: In the book, "we tell one story with different voices that represent all the women" from the region, Sancha said.
xho: Kulencwadi, "sibalisa ibali elinye ngamazwi ahlukeneyo amele bonke abafazi" bendawo, utshilo uSancha.
mt0: <pad> In the book, "we tell the same story in different voices that represent all women" of the village, said Sancha.</s>

en: Each offers a personal perspective on covering historic moments, including the collapse of autocratic governments, popular protest movements and war.
xho: Nganye ibonelela ngembono yobuqu malunga nokugubungela amaxesha embali, kubandakanya ukuwa koorhulumente bolawulo-melo, intshukumo yoqhanqalazo edumileyo kunye nemfazwe.
mt0: <pad> Each provides a personal perspective on covering historic periods, including the fall of monarchies, popular protests and wars.</s>

en: It also examines the discrimination and harassment women face in the newsroom and on assignment.
xho: Ikwavavanya ucalucalulo kunye nokuxhatshazwa kwabasetyhini abajongana nabo kwigumbi leendaba nakwizabelo.
mt0: <pad> She also investigated the prejudice and harassment she experienced with women in the press room and on the job.</s>

en: Understanding language and culture goes a long way toward making progress in the region, says Maya Gebeily.
xho: UMaya Gebeily uthi ukuqonda ulwimi nenkcubeko kunegalelo elikhulu ekwenzeni inkqubela kulo mmandla.
mt0: <pad> Maya Gebeily says that understanding the language and culture has a great impact on progress in the region.</s>

en: The Reuters bureau chief for Lebanon, Syria and Jordan is one of the contributors to the book.
xho: Umphathi we-Reuters Bureau yeLebhanon, iSyria kunye neJordani ngomnye wabanegalelo kule ncwadi.
mt0: <pad> The director of the Reuters Bureau for Lebanon, Syria and Jordan is one of the contributors to this book.</s>

en: There's a lot to say and show from the perspective of women reporters who were also then influenced by the women that they met as they were doing their reporting, she said.
xho: “Kuninzi okuthethwa nokuboniswa ngokwembono yeentathezli zasethyini nazo ezithi ziphenjelelwe ngamakhosikazi athe zadibana nawo ngethuba zisenza ingxelo,” utshilo.
mt0: <pad> "There is a lot of talk and evidence from the perspective of the rapists who also say they were interrogated by women they met when they made their report," he said.</s>

en: Born in the U.S. to Lebanese parents, Gebeily started her journalism career in 2013 with a local news site in Beirut, Lebanon. She went on to cover the region for Agence France-Presse before joining Reuters.
xho: Ozalelwe e-US kubazali baseLibanon, uGebeily waqala umsebenzi wakhe wobuntatheli ngo-2013 kwindawo yeendaba yasekhaya eBeirut, eLibanon. Uqhubekile nokugubungela ummandla we-Agence France-Presse ngaphambi kokujoyina iReuters.
mt0: <pad> Born in the US to Lebanon parents, Gebeily began his journalistic career in 2013 at a local news station in Beirut, Lebanon. He continued to cover the region for the Agence France-Presse before joining Reuters.</s>

en: Gebeily said her American and Lebanese background helped her understand the region better, which in turn has shaped her reporting.
xho: UGebeily uthe imvelaphi yakhe yaseMelika kunye neLibanon yamnceda ukuba awuqonde ngcono ummandla, nto leyo eye yabumba ingxelo yakhe.
mt0: <pad> Gebeily said his American and Lebanon backgrounds helped him understand the region better, which formed his report.</s>

en: Knowing the local language is an important part of that.
xho: Ukwazi ulwimi lwasekuhlaleni yinxalenye ebalulekileyo yoko.
mt0: <pad> Knowing the local language is a crucial part of that.</s>

en: When interviewing a minister or a displaced person or an activist, the most important element is getting their trust, she said.
xho: “Xa unodliwano-ndlebe nomphathiswa okanye umntu oshiye ikhaya okanye itshantliziyo, eyona nto ibalulekileyo kukufumana ukuthenjwa ngabo,” utshilo.
mt0: <pad> "When you interview a minister or a homeless person or a charitable person, the most important thing is to get their trust," he said.</s>

en: If you're able to speak the language and make them feel comfortable from the beginning, it changes everything.
xho: Ukuba uyakwazi ukuthetha ulwimi kwaye ubenze bazive bekhululekile kwasekuqaleni, oko kutshintsha yonke into.
mt0: <pad> If you can speak the language and make them feel comfortable from the start, that changes everything.</s>

en: It grants you a very beautiful kind of access.
xho: Ikunika uhlobo oluhle kakhulu lokufikelela. "
mt0: <pad> It gives you a great way of access.</s>

en: In addition to Iraq and Lebanon, Gebeily, 30, has also traveled to Syria to cover the war against the Islamic State (IS) militant group.
xho: Ukongeza e-Iraq naseLebhanon, uGebeily, oneminyaka engama-30 ubudala, naye uye waya eSyria ukuze apapashe imfazwe echasene neqela le-Islamic State (IS).
mt0: <pad> Beyond Iraq and Lebanon, Gebeily, 30, has also been to Syria to publish the war against the Islamic State (IS) group.</s>

en: Ive been very privileged to access some communities directly without having to work with a translator or a fixer, which also shapes the way that the stories come out, she said.
xho: “Ndibe nenyhweba yokufikelela kwiindawo ezithile zoluntu ngokuthe ngqo ngaphandle kokuba ndisebenze nomguquleli okanye umlungisi, nto leyo ebumba indlela aphuma ngayo amabali,” utshilo.
mt0: <pad> "I have had the privilege of being able to get in touch with some parts of the community directly without working with a translator or editor, which shapes the way stories are told," she said.</s>

en: Syrian-Kurdish journalist Khabat Abbas, who has covered the war in Syria, attests to the importance of that.
xho: Intatheli yaseSyria-Kurdish uKhabat Abbas, obhale ngemfazwe yaseSyria, uyangqina ukubaluleka koko.
mt0: <pad> The Syrian-Kurdish journalist Khabat Abbas, who has written about the Syrian war, confirms the importance of this.</s>

en: Its knowing the language and the culture that gives people a sense of comfort to open up to you, she told VOA from Qamishli, Syria.
xho: Kukwazi ulwimi kunye nenkcubeko eyenza abantu bazive bekhululekile ukuba bathethe nawe, uxelele iVOA evela eQamishli, eSiriya.
mt0: <pad> It's knowing the language and culture that makes people feel more comfortable to talk to you, he told VOA from Qamishli, Syria.</s>

en: That knowledge helped when Abbas, 34, was on assignment with Sancha in March 2021. They traveled to a Kurdish-run detention camp in northeast Syria ,
xho: Olo lwazi lwanceda xa uAbbas, oneminyaka engama-34 ubudala, ngethuba esebenza ngaphandle noSancha ngoMatshi 2021. Baya kwinkampu yamaKurdish ababevalelwe kumntla-mpuma weSiriya,
mt0: <pad> That knowledge helped Abbas, 34, when he was working outside Sancha in March 2021. They went to a Kurdish refugee camp in north-east Syria.</s>

en: And interviewed female jihadists affiliated with IS, for a story in El Pais.
xho: Babe nodliwano-ndlebe nama-jihadists abhinqileyo anxulumene ne-IS, ngebali e-El Pais.
mt0: <pad> They interviewed women jihadists affiliated with the Islamic State, a story in El Pais.</s>

en: While in Qamishli [in northeast Syria], I ran into two British journalists, very good colleagues of mine, who were disappointed after Shamima Begum and other women at the came refused to talk to them,
xho: “Ngethuba ndandiseQamishli [kumntla-mpuma weSyria], ndadibana neentatheli ezimbini zaseBritane, oogxa bam abalungileyo, ababedanile emva kukaShamima Begum nabanye namanye amanina enkampini ala ukuthetha nabo,
mt0: <pad> While I was in Qamishli [in north-eastern Syria], I met two British journalists, my good friends, who were devastated after Shamima Begum and other women in the camp refused to talk to them.</s>

en: " Sancha said, referring to a young woman who left her home in Britain aged 15 to join IS.
xho: ”utshilo uSancha, ebhekisa kumfazi oselula owashiya ikhaya lakhe eBritane eneminyaka eli-15 ukuya kujoyina i-IS.
mt0: <pad> "You don't know," said Sancha, referring to the young woman who left her home in Britain at 15 to join the Islamic State.</s>

en: Their fixer was a man, so the jihadist women didnt talk to them because they are radical, and they dont talk to men. But then I was able to sit with Shamima and other women, who gave fantastic interviews from inside their tents, Sancha said.
xho: Umlungisi wabo wayeyindoda, ngoko ke abafazi be-jihadist abazange bathethe nabo ngenxa yokuba abathethi namadoda. Kodwa ke ndakwazi ukuhlala noShamima kunye nabanye abafazi, abanikela udliwano-ndlebe oluhle ngaphakathi kweentente zabo,  Watsho uSancha.
mt0: <pad> Their supervisor was a man, so the jihadist women didn't talk to them because they don't talk to men. But I managed to stay with Shamima and other women, who gave me a good interview inside their tents, said Sancha.</s>

en: Abbas had a role in getting to talk to those women, she added.
xho: U-Abbas wayenefuthe ekufumaneni ukuthetha nabo bafazi, wongeze watsho.
mt0: <pad> Abbas had a great impact on the ability to talk to women, he added.</s>

en: Unlike Sancha and Gebeily, Abbas grew up in the marginalized Kurdish region of Syria, where until the war began in 2011, journalism effectively didnt exist.
xho: Ngokungafaniyo noSancha kunye noGebeily, u-Abbas wakhulela kwingingqi yaseKurdish yaseSyria, apho kwada kwaqala imfazwe ngo-2011, ubuntatheli babungekho.
mt0: <pad> Unlike Sancha and Gebeily, Abbas grew up in the Kurdish region of Syria, where until the war began in 2011, journalists were not present.</s>

en: Ordinary people in our region were used to seeing women pick up arms and fight, but they werent used to seeing a woman hold a camera on the streets and on front lines, Abbas said.
xho: “Abantu abaqhelekileyo kwingingqi yethu bebeqhele ukubona abantu basetyhini bethatha izixhobo kwaye besilwa, kodwa bebengaqhelanga ukubona umntu obhinqileyo ebambe ikhamera ezitratweni  nangaphambili,” utshilo u-Abbas.
mt0: <pad> "The ordinary people in our region were accustomed to seeing women taking weapons and fighting, but they were not accustomed to seeing a woman holding a camera in the streets and before," Abbas said.</s>

en: It took a lot of sacrificing for me to convince my family and society that Im as good, if not better, as my male colleagues.
xho: Kwathatha ukuzincama okukhulu ukuze ndiqinisekise usapho lwam kunye noluntu ukuba ndilungile, ukuba andingcono, njengabalingane bam abangamadoda.
mt0: <pad> It took great effort to convince my family and the public that I was good, that I wasn't better, than my male friends.</s>

en: Journalism appealed to her because the story of the Middle East has often been told by male journalists, both local and foreign.
xho: Ubuntatheli bamtsala umdla kuba ibali loMbindi Mpuma belisoloko libaliswa ziintatheli ezingamadoda, alapha ekhaya nakwamanye amazwe.
mt0: <pad> He was interested in journalism because the story of the Middle East had been told by men journalists, both local and international.</s>

en: The narrative hasnt changed because of that, but if local and international women journalists get a real chance to tell the story of the Middle East,
xho: Ibali alitshintshanga ngenxa yoko, kodwa ukuba iintatheli zasekhaya kunye nezamazwe ngamazwe zabasetyhini bafumana ithuba lokwenyani lokubalisa ibali loMbindi Mpuma,
mt0: <pad> The story didn't change because of it, but that local and international women journalists had a real chance to tell the story of the Middle East.</s>

en: that narrative could change, which would affect the way others see this region," Abbas said.
xho: ibali lingatshintsha, elinokuthi lichaphazele indlela abanye abawubona ngayo lo mmandla,”utshilo uAbbas.
mt0: <pad> The story could change, which could affect the way some people see this region," Abbas said.</s>

en: Sancha also believes women in journalism have an impact on the way issues are viewed in the region, including post-traumatic stress disorder and the effect it has on female health, and subjects such as violence and alcohol.
xho: U-Sancha naye ukholelwa ukuba abafazi kwi-journalism banempembelelo kwindlela imiba ejongwa ngayo kwingingqi, kubandakanywa uxinzelelo emva kokuphazamiseka kunye nomphumo onalo kwimpilo yabasetyhini, kunye nezifundo ezifana nobundlobongela kunye notywala.
mt0: <pad> Sancha also believes that women in journalism have an impact on the way issues are treated in the region, including post-traumatic stress and its effect on women's health, and topics such as violence and alcohol.</s>

en: We talk about all these issues that men normally would not speak about, she said.
xho: “Sithetha ngayo yonke le miba amadoda ebengafuni kuthetha ngayo,” utshilo.
mt0: <pad> "We talked about all the things that men wouldn't want to talk about," she said.</s>

en: Iran's Guards Commander Says Israel Creating Conditions for Own Destruction
xho: Umphathi wabalindi base-Iran uthi i-Israel izenzela iimeko zokuzitshabalalisa
mt0: <pad> Iran's chief of the guards says Israel is setting conditions for self-destruction.</s>

en: Israel's actions are creating conditions for its own destruction, Irans Revolutionary Guards commander on Friday told a Jerusalem Day rally at which the countrys new domestically-made Kheibar Buster missile was displayed.
xho: Izenzo ze-Israel zidala iimeko zokuzitshabalalisa, umphathi we Revolutionary Guards wase-Iran ngoLwesihlanu uxelele indibano yeJerusalem Day apho kwaboniswa khona imijukujelwa ye-Kheibar Buster eyenziwe ekhaya.
mt0: <pad> The actions of Israel create conditions for self-destruction, the head of the Revolutionary Guards of Iran on Thursday told a Jerusalem Day conference where they showed the home-made Kheibar Buster missile launchers.</s>

en: State television said millions of Iranians joined rallies marking Quds Day, the Arabic name for Jerusalem, in state-organized marches across the country.
xho: Umabonwakude welizwe uthe izigidi zabantu base-Irani bazibandakanya kwiindibano zokuphawula iQuds Day, igama lesiArabhu leJerusalem, kwimingcelele eququzelelwe ngurhulumente kwilizwe liphela.
mt0: <pad> The state television reported that millions of Iranians participated in rallies to mark Quds Day, the Arab name for Jerusalem, in government-organised marches throughout the country.</s>

en: It showed the Israeli flag being set on fire and groups of people around the country shouting choreographed "Death to America, Death to Israel" slogans.
xho: Ibonise iflegi yase-Israel itshiswa kwaye amaqela abantu kwilizwe lonke bekhwaza "Ukufa eMelika, Ukufa ku-Israel" izilogeni.
mt0: <pad> It showed the Israeli flag burned and a mob of people across the country chanting "Death to America, Death to Israel" on the flags.</s>

en: Supreme leader Ayatollah Ali Khamenei said in a televised speech that anti-Israeli protests and attacks showed that Palestinians rejected compromises by Arab authorities with Israel.
xho: Inkokeli ephakamileyo u-Ayatollah Ali Khamenei uthe kwintetho kamabonakude ukuba uqhanqalazo oluchasene ne-Israeli kunye nohlaselo lubonise ukuba abantu basePalestine bayala ukuthotyelwa ngabasemagunyeni baseArabhu kunye noSirayeli.
mt0: <pad> The Supreme Leader Ayatollah Ali Khamenei said in a televised address that the protests and attacks against Israel showed that the people of Palestine have refused to be respected by Arab and Israeli authorities.</s>

en: Opposition to Israel is a touchstone of belief for Iran, which backs Palestinian and Lebanese Islamist militant groups opposed to peace with Israel, which Tehran does not recognize.
xho: Ukuchaswa kwe-Israel ngumlinganiselo wokukholelwa kwi-Iran, exhasa amaqela e-Palestine kunye neLibanon yamaSilamsi achasene noxolo kunye ne-Israel, uTehran angawaniki ngqwalaselo.
mt0: <pad> The opposition to Israel is a standard of belief for Iran, supporting Palestinian and Lebanese Islamist groups opposing peace with Israel, Tehran not paying attention to them.</s>

en: What has happened in Palestine in recent years annuls all plans for compromise with the Zionist enemy (Israel) because no plan for Palestine can be implemented in the absence or contrary to the opinions of its owners, the Palestinians, Khamenei said, speaking in Arabic and addressing Palestinians and other Arabs.
xho: Into eyenzekileyo ePalestine kule minyaka idlulileyo itshitshisa zonke izicwangciso zokulalanisa notshaba lwaseZionist (Israeli) kuba akukho sicwangciso sePalestine esinokuthi siphunyezwe xa ingekho okanye ngokuchaseneyo nezimvo zabanini bayo, amaPalestine, utshilo uKhamenei. IsiArabhu kunye nokuthetha nabantu basePalestina kunye namanye ama-Arabhu.
mt0: <pad> The Palestine situation in the past years has blocked all plans to deal with the Zionist enemy (Israeli) because no plan for Palestine can be implemented without or against the opinion of its own people, the Palestinians, said Khamenei.</s>

en: Thus, Khamenei said, all previous peace agreements -- such as the 1993 Oslo Accords, the two-state solution to resolve the Israeli-Palestinian conflict,
xho: Ngoko, uKhamenei uthe, zonke izivumelwano zoxolo zangaphambili-ezinje nge-1993 Oslo Accords, isisombululo samazwe amabini ukusombulula impixano yase-Israel-Palestina,
mt0: <pad> So, the Ayatollah Khamenei said, all previous peace accords - such as the 1993 Oslo Accords - are two-state solution to solve Israel-Palestine conflict.</s>

en: And former U.S. President Donald Trump's plan dubbed the Deal of the Century "are null and void".
xho: Kwaye isicwangciso sowayesakuba nguMongameli waseMelika uDonald Trump esibizwa ngokuba yiDeal of the Century "ayinamsebenzi kwaye asinto".
mt0: <pad> And the plan of former US President Donald Trump's Deal of the Century "is useless and nothing."</s>

en: President Ebrahim Raisi, Irans military commanders and senior officials also attended the rallies in which people were allowed to march through the streets, the first time since the outbreak of the coronavirus pandemic two years ago.
xho: Umongameli u-Ebrahim Raisi, abalawuli basemkhosini base-Iran kunye namagosa aphezulu baye bazimasa iindibano apho abantu babevunyelwa ukuba baqhankqalaze ezitratweni, okokuqala okoko kwaqhambuka isifo esihlasele uzwelonke i-coronavirus kwiminyaka emibini edlulileyo.
mt0: <pad> President Ibrahim Raisi, military leaders in Iran and senior officials have called for protests where people were allowed to march in the streets, the first since the outbreak of the coronavirus pandemic in the country two years ago.</s>

en: Iran's Jerusalem Day rallies are held annually in support of Palestinians, who want East Jerusalem as the capital of a future state in territories captured by
xho: Imikhosi yase-Iran yeJerusalem Day ibanjwa minyaka le ukuxhasa abantu basePalestina, abafuna i-East Jerusalem ibe likomkhulu lelizwe elizayo kwiindawo ezithinjiweyo.
mt0: <pad> Iran's Jerusalem Day demonstrations are held every year to support the Palestinian people, who want East Jerusalem to be the capital of the future state in the occupied territories.</s>

en: Israel in a 1967 war, on the last Friday of the Muslim fasting month of Ramadan.
xho: I-Israel kwimfazwe ka-1967, ngoLwesihlanu wokugqibela wenyanga yokuzila ukutya yamaSilamsi yeRamadan.
mt0: <pad> Israel in the 1967 war, on Friday the last day of the Islamic fasting month of Ramadan.</s>

en: Stop your vicious deeds.
xho: Yekani izenzo zenu ezikhohlakeleyo.
mt0: <pad> Stop your evil behavior.</s>

en: You know well that we are people of action and reaction," Revolutionary Guards commander Hossein Salami, addressing Israel, told demonstrators in Tehran.
xho: Uyaya kakuhle ukuba singabantu abasebenzayo kunye abasabelayo,”umphathi wabaGadi beNguquko u-Hossein Salami, ethetha no-Israyeli, uxelele abaqhankqalazi eTehran.
mt0: <pad> He understands that we are people who work and respond," the head of the Guards of Revolution Hossein Salami told Tehran protesters.</s>

en: Our responses are painful.
xho: “Iimpendulo zethu zibuhlungu.
mt0: <pad> "Our responses are harsh.</s>

en: You create conditions for your own destruction.
xho: Udala iimeko zokutshabalalisa.
mt0: <pad> He has created destructive conditions.</s>

en: We will not leave you alone ...
xho: Asizokushiya wedwa...
mt0: <pad> We won't leave you alone.</s>

en: You know better than me what will befall you if you take evil action."
xho: Wazi ngcono kunam okuya kukwehlela xa uthe wathatha isenzo esibi.
mt0: <pad> You know better than I can tell you if you've done a bad thing.</s>

en: Iran's military has vowed to retaliate harshly against any attack by Israel, which has often voiced concern over the Iranian nuclear program.
xho: Umkhosi wase-Iran wenze isibhambathiso sokuziphindezela kabukhali kulo naluphi na uhlaselo lwe-Israel, esoloko ivakalisa inkxalabo ngenkqubo yenyukliya yase-Iran.
mt0: <pad> The military of Iran has promised to take a hard revenge on any Israel attack, which has always expressed concern about Iran's nuclear program.</s>

en: Tehran says the program is for peaceful purposes only.
xho: UTehran uthi le nkqubo yeyeenjongo zoxolo kuphela.
mt0: <pad> Tehran says the program is for only peace purposes.</s>

en: Israel, whose existence the Islamic Republic does not recognize, has long threatened military action against Iran if talks between Tehran and world powers fail to curb Iranian nuclear activity. Iran says its nuclear ambitions are peaceful.
xho: I-Israel, ubukho bayo i-Islamic Republic engabuboniyo, kudala isoyikisa ngenyathelo lomkhosi ngokuchasene ne-Iran ukuba iingxoxo phakathi kweTehran kunye namagunya ehlabathi ziyasilela ukunqanda umsebenzi wenyukliya waseIran. I-Iran ithi amabhongo ayo enyukliya aseluxolweni.
mt0: <pad> Israel, whose presence in the Islamic Republic is not officially recognized, has long been threatening with military action against Iran if international talks between Tehran and the world powers fail to stop Iran's nuclear program. Iran says its nuclear ambitions are safe.</s>

en: In February, the Islamic Republic unveiled its "Kheibar Buster" missile with a range of 1,450 km (900 miles).
xho: NgoFebruwari, i-Islamic Republic yatyhila umjukujelwa wayo othi "Kheibar Buster"  olunoluhlu lweekhilomitha ezili-1,450 (iimayile ezingama-900).
mt0: <pad> In February, the Islamic Republic unveiled its "Kheibar Buster" missile with a range of 1,450 kilometers (900 miles).</s>

en: Iran, which has one of the biggest missile programs in the Middle East, says its ballistic missiles have a range of up to 2,000 km (1,200 miles) and are capable of reaching its arch-foe Israel and U.S. bases in the region.
xho: I-Iran, eneyona nkqubo inkulu yemijukujelwa kuMbindi Mpuma, ithi imijukujelwa yayo ye-ballistic inoluhlu oluya kuthi ga kwi-2,000 yeekhilomitha (1,200 imayile) kwaye iyakwazi ukufikelela kutshaba lwayo olukhulu u-Israyeli kunye neziseko zase-US kulo mmandla.
mt0: <pad> Iran, with the biggest ballistic missile system in the Middle East, says its ballistic missile has a range of up to 2,000 kilometers (1,200 miles) and can hit its great enemy Israel and US bases in the region.</s>

en: Kheibar refers to an ancient Jewish oasis in the Arabian Peninsula's Hijaz region that was overrun by Muslim warriors in the 7th century.
xho: I-Kheibar ibhekisela kwindawo yamandulo yamaYuda yase-Arabia kwi-Hijaz ingingqi ye-Hijaz eyathi yahlaselwa ngamajoni amaSilamsi ngenkulungwane ye-7.
mt0: <pad> Kheibar refers to an ancient Arab Jewish place in the Hijaz region of the Hijaz which was attacked by Muslim troops in the 7th century.</s>

en: Tehran regards its ballistic missile program as an important deterrent against the United States, Israel and other adversaries, and has rejected Western demands to halt it.
xho: I-Tehran ithatha inkqubo yemijukujelwa njengesithintelo esibalulekileyo ngokuchasene ne-United States, i-Israel kunye nezinye iintshaba, kwaye izalile iimfuno zaseNtshona zokuyimisa.
mt0: <pad> Tehran sees the sanctions system as a crucial deterrent against the United States, Israel and other enemies, and has created Western demands to stop it.</s>

en: Over the past year, Iran and the United States have engaged in fitful, indirect talks in Vienna to revive a 2015 nuclear deal that then-President Donald Trump reneged on in 2018 and that Iran, in turn, began violating in 2019.
xho: Kunyaka ophelileyo, i-Iran kunye ne-United States ziye zabandakanyeka kwiingxoxo ezifanelekileyo, ezingathanga ngqo eVienna zokuvuselela isivumelwano senyukliya sonyaka ka-2015 awathi ngoko uMongameli uDonald Trump wasirhoxisa ngo-2018 kwaye i-Iran, nayo, yaqala ukowophula ngo-2019.
mt0: <pad> Last year, Iran and the United States have been engaged in constructive, non-direct talks in Vienna to revive the 2015 nuke deal that President Donald Trump then withdrew from in 2018 and Iran, too, began to violate it in 2019.</s>

en: Under the 2015 deal, Iran agreed to limit its nuclear program in return for relief from economic sanctions.
xho: Ngaphantsi kwesivumelwano sika-2015, i-Iran yavuma ukunciphisa inkqubo yayo yenyukliya ukuze ifumane isiqabu kwizohlwayo zezoqoqosho.
mt0: <pad> Under the 2015 deal, Iran agreed to limit its nuclear program to get an end to economic sanctions.</s>

en: While they appeared close to resurrecting the deal in March, talks stalled over last-minute Russian demands and whether Washington might drop Iran's Revolutionary Guards from its Foreign Terrorist Organization list.
xho: Ngelixa babonakala besondele ekuvuseni isivumelwano ngo-Matshi, iingxoxo zamisa kwiimfuno zaseRussia zomzuzu wokugqibela kunye nokuba iWashington inokulahla iRevolutionary Guards yase-Iran kuluhlu lwayo loMbutho wabanqolobi bangaphandle.
mt0: <pad> While they seemed close to reaching an agreement in March, talks stalled on last-minute Russian demands and whether Washington could remove the Iranian Revolutionary Guards from its list of International Terrorist Organization (IOTA) terrorist groups.</s>

en: As Fewer Americans Attend Church, Can Coffee Shops Fill the Void?
xho: Njengoko bambalwa abantu baseMelika abaya eCaweni, ingaba iivenkile zekofu zinako ukuzalisa ililize?
mt0: <pad> As few Americans go to the Vatican, can coffee shops fill the void?</s>

en: Churches and other houses of worship have historically played critical social and political functions in American society.
xho: Iicawe kunye nezinye izindlu zonqulo ngokwembali bezidlala indima ebalulekileyo yezentlalo nezopolitiko kuluntu lwaseMelika.
mt0: <pad> Churches and other religious institutions have traditionally played an important social and political role in the American community.</s>

en: But fewer people are attending religious services, and the decline of churches and other houses of worship threatens to leave a void that could potentially be filled by coffee shops.
xho: Kodwa bambalwa abantu abaya kwiinkonzo zonqulo, kwaye ukuwohloka kweecawe kunye nezinye izindlu zonqulo kusongela ukushiya indawo enokuthi ivalwe ziivenkile zekofu.
mt0: <pad> But few people go to church services, and the decline of churches and other religious buildings threatens to leave a space that could be closed by coffee shops.</s>

en: For so much of American history, the church has really been — or their congregations have really been — essential, providing an unheralded role in providing cohesion and connectedness in communities … encouraging civic engagement and political participation, says Daniel Cox, director of the Survey Center on American Life and a senior fellow at the American Enterprise Institute.
xho: Kwimbali enkulu yaseMelika, icawe ibiyeyona nto ibalulekileyo - okanye amabandla abo ebebalulekile, ebonelela ngendima engachazwanga ekuboneleleni ngentsebenziswano kunye nokunxibelelana eluntwini ... Iziko loPhando kuBomi baseMelika kunye nomntu ophezulu kwiZiko loShishino laseMelika.
mt0: <pad> In the great American history, churches have been a key component - or their important churches, providing an undisguised role in providing social cohesion and communication to the community... Center for American Life Research and a senior member of the American Economic Society</s>

en: It was not happenstance or luck that the civil rights movement emerged out of the church, Cox says.
xho: “Ayizange ibe sisenzeko nje okanye ithamsanqa ukuba umbutho wamalungelo abantu uphume ecaweni,” utshilo uCox.
mt0: <pad> "It's never just a coincidence or a chance that a human rights organization comes out of church," said Cox.</s>

en: And you see that cross-culturally … whether it's in predominantly white rural communities, in the suburbs, wherever, churches have historically been really, really important.
xho: Kwaye uyayibona loo nto ngokwenkcubeko ... nokuba kukwiindawo ezihlala abantu abamhlophe ubukhulu becala, kwiindawo ezisemaphandleni, naphi na apho, iicawe bezikade zibalulekile ngokwembali.
mt0: <pad> And you see that culturally... although it's mostly white-dominated areas, rural areas, anywhere, churches have been important in history.</s>

en: Churches and other houses of worship have also played a role in helping immigrants assimilate once they arrive in America, Cox says.
xho: Iinkonzo kunye nezinye izindlu zonqulo nazo ziye zadlala indima ekuncedeni abantu abavela kwamanye amazwe ukuba bafane bakuba befikile eMelika, utshilo uCox.
mt0: <pad> Churches and other religious institutions have also played a role in helping immigrants feel more comfortable when they arrived in the United States, Cox said.</s>

en: In 1999, 70% of Americans said they belonged to a church, mosque or synagogue.
xho: Ngo-1999, i-70% yabantu baseMelika bathi bangamalungu enkonzo, i-mosque okanye indlu yesikhungu.
mt0: <pad> In 1999, 70% of Americans said they were members of a church, mosque or community center.</s>

en: By 2020, that number had dropped to 47%.
xho: Ngo-2020, elo nani lehle laya kutsho kuma-47%.
mt0: <pad> In 2020, this number fell to 47%.</s>

en: A 2019 survey found that only about three in 10 Americans say they attend weekly religious services.
xho: Uvavanyo luka-2019 lufumanise ukuba bathathu kwabalishumi abantu baseMelika abathi baya kwiinkonzo zeveki ngeveki.
mt0: <pad> A 2019 survey found that three out of every ten Americans who said they went to church every week were not.</s>

en: Third places  Lack of involvement and affiliation with churches, mosques and synagogues means people might be missing out on what urban sociologist Ray
xho: Iindawo zesithathu Ukunqongophala kokubandakanyeka kunye nokuzibandakanya neecawe, iimosque kunye nezindlu zesikhungu kuthetha ukuba abantu banokuphoswa yintoni isazi ngentlalo yoluntu uRay.
mt0: <pad> The Third Space The lack of involvement and engagement with churches, mosques and community centers means that people may be misinformed about what we know about social science Ray</s>

en: Oldenburg dubbed as "third places" — public gathering spots that offer something that home, the "first place," and work, the "second place," might not.
xho: U-Oldenburg ezibizwa ngokuba  "ziindawo zesithathu" - iindawo zokuhlanganisana zikawonke-wonke ezibonelela ngento ethile ekhaya, "indawo yokuqala," kunye nomsebenzi, "indawo yesibini," azingenako zona.
mt0: <pad> Oldenburg's so-called "third places" - public meeting spaces that offer something of home, "first place," and work, "second place," that they cannot provide.</s>

en: Oldenburg argued that third places are critical to a communitys social vitality.
xho: U-Oldenburg waxoxa ukuba iindawo zesithathu zibalulekile kubomi boluntu ekuhlaleni.
mt0: <pad> Oldenburg argued that the third space was important for the social life of the local community.</s>

en: An October 2021 survey conducted by the American Survey Center found that commercial spaces like coffee houses foster trust and connection in American communities and could help fill the void left by churches.
xho: Uphando luka-Okthobha ku-2021 olwenziwa yiAmerican Survey Center lufumanise ukuba iindawo zorhwebo njengezindlu zekofu zikhuthaza ukuthembana kunye noqhagamshelo kuluntu lwaseMelika kwaye inokunceda ukuvala isithuba esishiywe ziinkonzo.
mt0: <pad> The American Survey Center's October 2021 study found that commercial spaces like coffee shops promote trust and connection in the American community and can help fill the gap left by services.</s>

en: If you're a regular at a cafe, the barista may know what you usually order, and they can make it for you, and that feels good, says clinical psychologist Dr.
xho: Ukuba uqhelekile kwindawo yokusela ikofu, umenzi kofu unokuyazi into oqhele ukuyi-odola, kwaye bakwenzele yona, kwaye oko kuvakala kulungile, utsholo ugqirha wolwazi ngengqondo.
mt0: <pad> If you're a regular at a coffee shop, the bartender may know what you're usually ordering, and will do it for you, and that feels good, said a psychiatrist.</s>

en: Maria Espinola, an assistant professor in the Department of Psychiatry and Behavioral Neuroscience at the University of Cincinnati College of Medicine.
xho: UMaria Espinola, unjingalwazi oncedisayo kwiDepartment of Psychiatry and Behavioural Neuroscience kwiYunivesithi yaseCincinnati College of Medicine.
mt0: <pad> Maria Espinola, a professor of psychiatry and behavioral neuroscience at the University of Cincinnati College of Medicine.</s>

en: It feels good to be recognized, to know that people are expecting you, to know that people care about you, to know that you belong, because the need for belonging and human connection is a fundamental need that we all have, and it's important to have that fulfilled in different ways, Espinola says.
xho: Kuvakala kumnandi ukuqatshelwa, ukwazi ukuba abantu bakulindele, ukwazi ukuba abantu bakukhathalele, ukwazi ukuba unendawo, kuba imfuno yokuba nendawo kunye nokunxibelelana kwabantu sisidingo esisisiseko esinayo sonke, kwaye kubalulekile. ukuba oko kuzalisekiswe ngeendlela ezahlukeneyo,”utshilo uEspinola.
mt0: <pad> It feels good to be recognized, to know that people are waiting for you, to know that people care about you, to know that you have a place, because the need for space and social communication is a fundamental need that we all have, and it's important that it be fulfilled in different ways," Espinola said.</s>

en: So, places like third places can allow us to do that.
xho: Ke, iindawo ezinjengeendawo zesithathu zinokusivumela ukuba senze loo nto.
mt0: <pad> So, places like the third world can allow us to do that.</s>

en: In the past, churches and other houses of worship have been a third place for many Americans.
xho: Ngaphambili, iinkonzo nezinye izindlu zonqulo beziyindawo yesithathu kubantu abaninzi baseMerika.
mt0: <pad> Before, churches and other religious buildings were the third most important place for many Americans.</s>

en: In 2019, 67% of people surveyed said they have a third place
xho: Ngo-2019, iipesenti ezingama-67 zabantu abaphononongwayo bathi banendawo yesithathu
mt0: <pad> In 2019, 67% of people surveyed said they were in the third place.</s>

en: a coffee shop, bar, restaurant, park or other places in their community that they visit regularly.
xho: ivenkile yekofu, indawo yokusela, indawo yokutya, ipaki okanye ezinye iindawo kwiindawo abahlala kuzo abazindwendwela rhoqo.
mt0: <pad> coffee shop, bar, restaurant, park or other places in their neighborhoods that they frequently visit.</s>

en: That number dropped to 56% in 2021 — a number that could have been affected by the COVID-19 pandemic.
xho: Elo nani lehle laya kutsho kwi-56% ngo-2021 - inani elinokuchatshazelwa sisifo sikazwelonke i-COVID-19.
mt0: <pad> This number will fall to 56% in 2021 - the number affected by the national epidemic COVID-19.</s>

en: What we found was that people who had a third place were much more connected to their community, says Cox.
xho: “Into esiyifumeneyo kukuba abantu ababenendawo yesithathu banxibelelene kakhulu noluntu lwabo,” utshilo uCox.
mt0: <pad> "What we found is that the people who were in the third place were very close to their community," said Cox.</s>

en: They're much more likely to engage in other activities there.
xho: “Babonakala besenza ezinye izinto apho.
mt0: <pad> "They seem to be doing something there.</s>

en: They are much more trusting of their neighbors. There's a whole great array of positive social outcomes that were connected to having a third place … and for a lot of Americans, it's a coffee shop or a cafe."
xho: Bakholose ngakumbi ngabamelwane babo. Kukho uluhlu olukhulu lweziphumo ezilungileyo zentlalo ezidityaniswe nokuba nendawo yesithathu ... kwaye kubantu abaninzi baseMelika, yivenkile yekofu okanye ikhefi. "
mt0: <pad> They are more trusting of their neighbors. There are many good social effects associated with having a third place... and for many Americans, it is a coffee shop or a coffee shop.</s>

en: What coffee shops have in their favor is that they can be found almost everywhere, all over the country,
xho: Into iivenkile zekofu ezinayo ezizisebenzelayo kukuba zifumaneka phantse kuyo yonke indawo, kulo lonke ilizwe,
mt0: <pad> The thing that makes coffee shops so attractive is that they are almost everywhere, all over the country.</s>

en: And anyone who wants to can stop by regularly.
xho: Kwaye nabani na ofuna ukuya angaya rhoqo.
mt0: <pad> And anyone who wants to go can go there often.</s>

en: And many are open most days of the week.
xho: Kwaye ezininzi zivuliwe iintsuku ezininzi zeveki.
mt0: <pad> And many are open for many days of the week.</s>

en: Cox says even brief coffee shop encounters can increase a sense of belonging.
xho: U-Cox uthi kwa iindibano ezimfutshane kwivenkile yekofu zinokunyusa imvakalelo yokuba izive unendawo.
mt0: <pad> U-Cox says even short meetings in a coffee shop can boost the sense of belonging.</s>

en: I think there's a lot of potential here, and a lot of it is unrealized potential, Cox says.
xho: “Ndicinga ukuba zininzi izinto ezinokwenzeka apha, kwaye uninzi lwazo lunezinto ezingekafezekiswa,” utshilo uCox.
mt0: <pad> "I think there are a lot of things that can be done here, and most of them have nothing to do with it," Cox said.</s>

en: But in terms of what they could do, there's a lot there.
xho: Kodwa malunga nento abanokuyenza, kuninzi apho.
mt0: <pad> But about what they can do, there's a lot there.</s>

en: I've been in places where the same group of folks come in there to play chess.
xho: Ndikhe ndakwiindawo apho iqela elifanayo labantu liza kudlala ichess.
mt0: <pad> I've been to a place where the same group of people would come to play chess.</s>

en: Or they have their informal bunch of retirees. …
xho: Okanye baneqela labo elingekho sikweni labadlali abathathe umhlala-phantsi. …
mt0: <pad> Or they have their own unofficial team of retired players.</s>

en: They just got together, and they talked and chatted and caught up with each other. …
xho: Badibana nje, bancokola bancokola baxelelana ngobomi babo. …
mt0: <pad> They just met, chatted and talked about their lives.</s>

en: I don't know where else they would have gone — maybe a church, but maybe not — to share information, to encourage each other to maybe get involved in an activity.
xho: Andazi ukuba bebengaya ngaphi na—mhlawumbi ecaweni, kodwa mhlawumbi hayi—ukwabelana ngolwazi, ukukhuthazana ukuba mhlawumbi babandakanyeke kumsebenzi othile.
mt0: <pad> I don't know where they might meet—maybe at church, but maybe not—sharing information, encouraging each other to maybe participate in some kind of activity.</s>

en: And I think that is what is so powerful about coffee shops."
xho: Kwaye ndicinga ukuba le yeyona nto inamandla malunga neevenkile zekofu. "
mt0: <pad> And I think that's the most powerful thing about coffee shops.</s>

en: Are COVID-19 Restrictions Stunting Children’s Immune Systems?
xho: Ingaba izithintelo ze-COVID-19 ziyawoyisa amajoni omzimba abantwana?
mt0: <pad> Do the restrictions on COVID-19 weaken children's immune systems?</s>

en: Some medical experts have expressed concern that COVID-19 preventative measures, like masking and remote schooling, are potentially weakening childrens immune systems by shielding them from the usual childhood illnesses.
xho: Ezinye iingcali zonyango zivakalise inkxalabo yokuba amanyathelo othintelo lwe-COVID-19, njengokugquma imaski kunye nokufundela emakhaya, anokuthi enze buthathaka amajoni omzimba wabantwana ngokubakhusela kwizigulo eziqhelekileyo zobuntwana.
mt0: <pad> Some medical experts expressed concern that measures to prevent COVID-19, such as wearing masks and homeschooling, may make children's immune systems weaker by protecting them from common childhood infections.</s>

en: There are a lot of reasons to believe that kids need to be exposed to things to keep their immunity complex, so that should they encounter something very dangerous, they have aspects of their immunity that might cross over and help protect them against those things, says Sara Sawyer, a professor of molecular, cellular and developmental biology at the University of Colorado Boulder.
xho: Zininzi izizathu zokukholelwa ukuba abantwana kufuneka bavezwe kwizinto zokugcina amajoni emizimba yabo enamandla, ukuze ukuba bathe badibana nento eyingozi kakhulu, banamanye amajoni omzimba okunokuthi awele kwaye ancede abakhusele kwezo zinto. Utsho uSara Sawyer, unjingalwazi webhayoloji yemolekyuli, yeselula kunye nophuhliso kwiYunivesithi yaseColorado Boulder.
mt0: <pad> There are many reasons to believe that children should be exposed to things that can strengthen their immune systems, so that if they meet something very dangerous, they have other immune systems that can fall and help them protect themselves. Sara Sawyer, professor of molecular, cell and developmental biology at the University of Colorado Boulder, says.</s>

en: At birth, vulnerable infants get antibodies from their mothers breast milk, which helps protect them until they can build their own immunity.
xho: Ekuzalweni, iintsana ezisesichengeni zifumana izilwa-buhlungu ezisuka kunina kubisi lwebele, oluzinceda luzikhusele de zibe nokwakha owazo amajoni omzimba.
mt0: <pad> At birth, babies in danger receive their mother's antibodies in the milk of their mother, which helps them to protect themselves until they can build their own immune system.</s>

en: Its no accident that babies start putting things in their mouths as soon as they gain enough dexterity to pick things up.
xho: Akuyongozi ukuba iintsana ziqalise ukubeka izinto emilonyeni yazo ngokukhawuleza nje ukuba zizuze ubugcisa obaneleyo bokuthatha izinto.
mt0: <pad> It is not unusual for babies to start putting things in their mouths as soon as they develop enough skills to pick up things.</s>

en: They're doing that because they're sampling the environment and building their immunity.
xho: “Bayenza loo nto ngenxa yokuba bavavanya imekobume kwaye bakha amajoni omzimba.
mt0: <pad> "They do that because they test for their own DNA and build their own immune systems.</s>

en: That's an evolutionary trait," Sawyer says.
xho: Luphawu lokutshintsha kwezinto,” utshilo uSawyer.
mt0: <pad> It's a sign of change," said Sawyer.</s>

en: Theyre exposing their body to germs in a certain, level way to build their immunity.
xho: “Baveza imizimba yabo kwiintsholongwane ngendlela ethile, ekumgangatho wokwakha amajoni emizimba yabo.
mt0: <pad> "They exposed their bodies to bacterial infections in a way that was characteristic of building their body's defenses."</s>

en: So, some people would argue that childhood illnesses, like colds and stomach bugs, build our immunity so that when more dangerous things come along, we're prepared and we don't get as sick from those more dangerous things."
xho: Ngoko ke, abanye abantu banokuthi izigulo zobuntwana, ezinjengokubanda kunye nesisu, zakha amajoni omzimba ukuze xa kuvela izinto eziyingozi ngakumbi, sizilungiselele kwaye singaguli ngenxa yezo zinto ziyingozi."
mt0: <pad> So, some people may say that childhood illnesses, such as cold and diarrhea, build up the immune system so that when more dangerous things come, we are prepared and not ill from those dangerous things.</s>

en: Even before the pandemic, epidemiological evidence suggested that children in more developed countries, where handwashing and the use of sanitizer are more prevalent, might have less-developed immune systems compared to kids in developing nations who are routinely exposed to more bacteria, viruses and allergens.
xho: Ngaphambi kwesifo sikazwelonke, ubungqina be-epidemiology bacebisa ukuba abantwana abakumazwe aphuhlileyo, apho ukuhlanjwa kwezandla kunye nokusetyenziswa kwesicoci sezifo kuxhaphake kakhulu, banokuba namajoni omzimba angaphuhlisiyo xa kuthelekiswa nabantwana abakumazwe asakhasayo abasoloko bedibana neebhaktheriya ezininzi, iintsholongwane kunye nezinto ezinokuthi zenzeke.
mt0: <pad> Before the national epidemic, epidemiologic evidence suggested that children in developed countries, where handwashing and the use of sanitizers are common, may have weaker immune systems compared to children in developing countries who are constantly exposed to many bacteries, viruses and potentially harmful things.</s>

en: This makes kids in more industrialized countries more vulnerable to developing autoimmune diseases, according to whats known as the "hygiene hypothesis."
xho: Oku kwenza abantwana kumazwe ahambela phambili kwezoqoqosho babe sesichengeni sokuphuhlisa izifo ezizimelayo, ezaziwa ngokuba yi "hygiene hypothesis."
mt0: <pad> This makes children in developing economies at risk of developing infectious diseases, known as the "hygiene hypothesis."</s>

en: The hygiene hypothesis is actually quite controversial because it's thought that our exposure to microbes isn't the only factor, says Cody Warren, a virologist and immunologist who is a postdoctoral fellow at the University of Colorado Boulder.
xho: “IHygiene Hyphothesis eneneni iyaxabanisa kuba kucingelwa ukuba ukudibana kwethu neentsholongwane ayisiyiyo yodwa into,” utshilo uCody Warren, ugqirha wentsholongwane kunye nogcino lwamajoni omzimba osebenza  kwiYunivesithi yaseColorado Boulder.
mt0: <pad> “The Hygiene Hyphothesis is really confusing because it thinks that our encounter with germs is not just one thing,” said Dr. Cody Warren, an infectious disease and immunology doctor at the University of Colorado Boulder.</s>

en: A lot of this could also be dictated by genetics, diet, and the environment that we live in.
xho: “Uninzi lwale nto lunokuchazwa lufuzo, ukutya, kunye nendawo esihlala kuyo.
mt0: <pad> "Most of this can be explained by our genes, food, and the environment in which we live."</s>

en: That also shapes our immune system… it's a real multifactorial thing that we can't fully account for just by wearing masks.
xho: Oku kubumba amajoni ethu omzimba… yinto yokwenyani enezinto ezininzi esingenako ukuziphendulela ngokupheleleyo ngokunxiba iimaski.
mt0: <pad> This makes up our body's immune system... it's a real thing with many things we can't completely respond to by wearing masks.</s>

en: There are other things that go into that equation."
xho: Kukho ezinye izinto ezingena kulo mba."
mt0: <pad> There are some things that can't be brought into this world.</s>

en: Warren, the father of three young children, says spending lots of time outdoors is one way to balance the negatives of isolation.
xho: UWarren, utata wabantwana abathathu abancinci, uthi ukuchitha ixesha elininzi ngaphandle yenye yeendlela zokulinganisa izinto ezingalunganga zokuba wedwa.
mt0: <pad> Warren, the father of three young children, says spending a lot of time outdoors is one way to counteract the negativity of being alone.</s>

en: Just exploring microbes in the environment also is benefiting [and] training our immune system, Warren says.
xho: “Ukuphonononga nje iintsholongwane kwindawo esingqongileyo kuluncedo [kwaye] nokuqeqesha amajoni ethu omzimba,” utshilo uWarren.
mt0: <pad> "Just killing the germs in a critical environment is helpful [and] training our body defense," said Warren.</s>

en: Our immune systems get trained through the foods that we eat, which also have microorganisms on them.
xho: “Amajoni ethu omzimba aqeqeshwa ngokutya esikutyayo, okunezinto ezincinci esingaziboniyo kuko.
mt0: <pad> Our body soldiers are trained by the food we eat, there are small things we don't see because we don't know.</s>

en: And so, despite the fact that we've kind of been hunkered down a little bit, I do feel that our immune systems will catch up."
xho: Kwaye ke, ngaphandle kwento yokuba sikhe sabambeka kancinci, diyaqonda ukukuba amajoni ethu omzimba azakubambelela.”
mt0: <pad> And so, except for a little discomfort, we know that our bodyguards will hold on to you.</s>

en: There are other things parents can do, he says, to boost their childrens immune systems during pandemic times.
xho: Kukho ezinye izinto abazali abanokuzenza, utsho, ukomeleza amajoni omzimba kubantwana babo ngamaxesha obhubhane.
mt0: <pad> There are some things parents can do, he says, to strengthen the immune system of their children during an epidemic.</s>

en: One of the most important things you can do is just to stay up to date on vaccines.
xho: “Enye yezona zinto zibalulekileyo onokuthi uzenze kukuhlala usexesheni ngezitofu zokugonya.
mt0: <pad> One of the most important things you can do is to stay on the vaccination schedule.</s>

en: That's one of the best ways that we have to train our immune systems," Warren says.
xho: Le yenye yeendlela ezilungileyo ekufuneka siqeqeshele amajoni ethu omzimba,” utshilo uWarren.
mt0: <pad> This is one of the best ways we can train our troops,” said Warren.</s>

en: But also, equally important is making sure our children have a good diet and they regulate stress.
xho: Kodwa kwakhona, okubaluleke ngokulinganayo kukuqinisekisa ukuba abantwana bethu banokutya okufanelekileyo kwaye balawula uxinzelelo.
mt0: <pad> But again, just as important is to ensure that our children have the right diet and manage stress.</s>

en: It's been well documented that both of those — having a good diet, a less stressful environment — can have a positive impact on our immune system."
xho: Kubhalwe kakuhle ukuba zombini ezi-zokutya okulungileyo, indawo ephantsi koxinzelelo-zinokuba nefuthe elihle kumajoni ethu omzimba. "
mt0: <pad> It is well known that both of these-healthy diet, stressful environment-can have a bad effect on our body's immune system.</s>

en: Once public health officials say masks are no longer necessary, Sawyer thinks pointing out the positives of putting our masks away could reassure hesitant parents who worry about their children getting sick.
xho: Nje ukuba amagosa ezempilo karhulumente athi iimaski azisafuneki, uSawyer ucinga ukuba ukukhomba izinto ezintle zokubeka iimaski zethu kunokuqinisekisa abazali abathandabuzayo abanexhala lokugula kwabantwana babo.
mt0: <pad> Once government health officials say masks are no longer needed, Sawyer thinks that pointing out the good things about wearing our masks might convince doubtful parents who fear for the health of their children.</s>

en: Maybe we should have a public conversation about the possible reasons to take that mask off, if they are in school, and get back to the normal repertoire of relatively safe childhood illnesses, she says.
xho: “Mhlawumbi kufuneka sibe nencoko esidlangalaleni malunga nezizathu ezinokubakho zokususa lo maski, ukuba basesikolweni, kwaye sibuyele kwindawo eqhelekileyo yezigulo zobuntwana ezikhuselekileyo,” utshilo.
mt0: <pad> "Maybe we need to have a public conversation about the possibility of removing this mask, if they are in school, and returning to our normal childhood playgrounds," he said.</s>

en: The plus side of childhood illnesses is that they can build up that hornet's nest of immunity that could protect kids aagainst new things that then come along.
xho: Elona cala libalaseleyo lezigulo zobuntwana kukuba banokwakha indlwane ye-hornet yokungakhuseleki enokukhusela abantwana kwizinto ezintsha ezizayo.
mt0: <pad> The most important benefit of childbirth is that they can build a safe haven for children that will protect them from new things that may come.</s>

en: World Bank, Nike Team Up for 'The Girl Effect' Initiative
xho: IWolrd Bank, iqela likaNike ziyasebenzisana ngenxa 'ye The Girl Effect'
mt0: <pad> The World Bank, Nike team are working together for the "The Girl Effect."</s>

en: The Adolescent Girls Initiative partners the World Bank, the Nike Foundation and governments of developing and developed nations to empower girls in poor countries.
xho: I-Adolescent Girls Initiative isebenzisana neWorld Bank, i-Nike Foundation kunye noorhulumente bezizwe eziphuhlayo kunye neziphuhlileyo ukuxhobisa amantombazana kumazwe ahluphekileyo.
mt0: <pad> The Adolescent Girls Initiative works with the World Bank, Nike Foundation and governments of developing and developed countries to empower girls in poor countries.</s>

en: The two-year-old program is helping girls in Asia, Africa and the Middle East gain the education and skills they need to transition into the workforce.
xho: Inkqubo eneminyaka emibini ubudala inceda amantombazana aseAsia, eAfrika naseMbindi Mpuma ukuba afumane imfundo kunye nezakhono ezifunekayo ukuze atshintshele emsebenzini.
mt0: <pad> The two-year program helps girls from Asia, Africa and the Middle East to get education and skills needed to change careers.</s>

en: Activist Donatella Rostagno, from the European network for Central Africa, accompanied Bihamba on her trip to the United States.

en: Rostagno also said feels, however, the international community is not doing enough to stop Congo's war, despite having a large U.N. peacekeeping mission there.

en: The majority of the actions is made to look at the consequences, to work with the women who are victims, but not enough is done to look at the causes of the rapes and the conflict, said Rostagno.

en: Deteriorating situation amid global concern.

en: Rostagno explained that foreign non-governmental organizations get funding to tackle the issue of sexual violence, but local organizations often get ignored.
xho: URostagno ucacisile ukuba imibutho yangaphandle engekho phantsi kukarhulumente ifumana inkxaso-mali yokuqubisana nomba wobundlobongela obuphathelele kwezesondo, kodwa imibutho yasekuhlaleni ihlala ingahoywa.
mt0: <pad> ROstangno explained that international non-governmental organizations receive funding to fight sexual violence, but local organizations are often ignored.</s>

en: She said complex applications to get outside funding favor bigger organizations.

mt0: <pad> They can just make it, send it, and get the money.</s>

en: The problem is that the money in most cases is spent to pay for the fixed cost of the organization, for the salaries of expat people coming to the region and to the country, while the local non-governmental organizations, those working with the communities, with the women, with the children, in the villages, those who need need money to survive in order to do their work do not have access," said Rostagno.
xho: Ingxaki kukuba imali kwiimeko ezininzi isetyenziselwa ukuhlawula iindleko ezimiselweyo zombutho, kwimivuzo yabantu abaphuma kwamanye amazwe beza kummandla kunye nelizwe, ngelixa imibutho engekho phantsi korhulumente, abo basebenzisana noluntu, kunye nabasetyhini, nabantwana, ezilalini, abo bafuna imali ukuze baphile ukuze benze umsebenzi wabo abanakho ukufikelela, "utshilo uRostagno.
mt0: <pad> The problem is that the money is often used to pay for the fixed costs of the organization, for the wages of foreigners who come to the region and the country, while non-governmental organizations, those working with the community, with women and children, in the rural areas, who need money to live and do their work cannot get it," said Rossagno.</s>

en: Bihamba said Congolese soldiers should be paid directly through bank withdrawals, rather than being paid through their superiors.

mt0: <pad> Bihamba said under the current system they only receive half their salary, causing some soldiers to riot and rob.</s>

mt0: <pad> "God has mercy on us," he said. The retired Bishop of Tsetse announced that he will step down from public life on his birthday.</s>

en: The time has come to slow down, and sip maybe rooibos tea with my beloved wife in the afternoons he said.

en: Tutu rose through the ranks of the Anglican church in South Africa to become the first black Anglican archbishop of Capetown.
xho: UTutu wenyuka kwinkonzo yamaTshetshi eMzantsi Afrika waba ngu-archbishophu wokuqala omnyama waseTshetshi eKapa.
mt0: <pad> Tutu went up in the Scottish church in South Africa and became the first black archbishop of the Scottish Church in Cape Town.</s>

en: He was a vocal critic of South Africa's white-ruled government and encouraged non-violence to end apartheid.
xho: Wayengumgxeka kakhulu urhulumente woMzantsi Afrika owawulawulwa ngabamhlophe kwaye wayekhuthaza ukungaphathwa ngobundlobongela ukuze kupheliswe ucalucalulo.
mt0: <pad> He was a strong critic of the white-run South African government and promoted nonviolence to end apartheid.</s>

en: Tutu was the recipient of many awards, and in 1984, he received a Nobel Peace Prize for advocating "a democratic and just society without racial divisions.
xho: UTutu nguye owafumana iimbasa ezininzi, kwaye ngo-1984, wafumana iwonga leNobel Peace Prize ngokumela "uluntu lwedemokhrasi nolunobulungisa ngaphandle kocalucalulo ngokobuhlanga.
mt0: <pad> Tutu is the most awarded person, and in 1984 he received the Nobel Peace Prize for his "commitment to a democratic and fair society without racial discrimination."</s>

en: He used the recognition to step up the anti-apartheid campaign, calling for an economic boycott against South Africa.
xho: “Wasebenzisa olu lwazi ukuqinisa iphulo lokuchasa ucalu-calulo, ememelela ukuba kugxothwe uMzantsi Afrika kwezoqoqosho.
mt0: <pad> He used this knowledge to strengthen his campaign against discrimination, calling for the expulsion of South Africa from economic competition.</s>

en: After the end of apartheid, Tutu called it an incredible day when Nelson Mandela won South Africa's first all-race elections.
xho: Emva kokuphela kocalucalulo, uTutu wayibiza ngokuba yimini engakholelekiyo xa uNelson Mandela ephumelele unyulo lokuqala lweentlanga zonke eMzantsi Afrika.
mt0: <pad> After the end of the apartheid, Tutu called it an unbelievable day when Nelson Mandela won the first all-race election in South Africa.</s>

en: I would say the highest point for me was when I stood on the balcony in 1994 to introduce our new, brand new president to South Africa and the world, he said.
xho: “Ndingathi eyona nto iphezulu kum kuxa ndandimi ebhalkhoni ngo-1994 ndisazisa umongameli wethu omtsha kraca eMzantsi Afrika nehlabathi,” utshilo.
mt0: <pad> "The most proud moment for me was when I stood on the balcony in 1994 to congratulate our new president, Nelson Mandela, on his work for South Africa and the world," he said.</s>

en: To help mend the nation, President Mandela appointed Tutu as head of the country's Truth and Reconciliation Commission.
xho: Ukunceda isizwe, uMongameli Mandela wonyula uTutu njengentloko yeKomishoni yeNyaniso noXolelwaniso yelizwe.
mt0: <pad> To help the nation, President Mandela appointed Tutu as the head of the National Commission on Truth and Reconciliation.</s>

en: The group issued a report that included numerous confessions of guilt under apartheid in return for amnesty.
xho: Eli qela likhuphe ingxelo equka izivumo ezininzi zetyala phantsi kocalucalulo ukuze kuxolelwe.
mt0: <pad> The group released a report that included many convictions under the apartheid system for forgiveness.</s>

en: It makes specific proposals on how we can cultivate a culture of human rights and of structures to insure that the atrocities of the past will not reoccur, Tutu said.
xho: “Yenza izindululo ezithe ngqo malunga nokuba singayihlakulela njani inkcubeko yamalungelo oluntu kunye neziseko zokuqinisekisa ukuba izenzo zenkohlakalo zangaphambili azizukwenzeka kwakhona,” utshilo uTutu.
mt0: <pad> "It made very specific recommendations on how we can develop a culture of human rights and the foundations to ensure that past atrocities will not happen again," Tutu said.</s>

en: Tutu also campaigned to fight poverty and AIDS.
xho: UTutu ukwakhankasele ukulwa intlupheko kunye nogawulayo.
mt0: <pad> Tutu has focused on combating poverty and diabetes.</s>

en: In recent years, he expressed his disappointment in post-apartheid South Africa, especially the level of violent crime.
xho: Kwiminyaka yakutshanje, uvakalise ukuphoxeka kwakhe kuMzantsi Afrika wasemva kocalucalulo, ingakumbi izinga lolwaphulo-mthetho olunobundlobongela.
mt0: <pad> In recent years, he has expressed his discontent with the post-apartheid South Africa, especially the high level of violent crime.</s>

en: Despite his withdrawal from public life, Tutu says he will continue to support his peace foundation and will remain part of a group of elder statesmen who campaign for peace and human rights.
xho: Ngaphandle kokurhoxa kubomi boluntu, uTutu uthi uzakuqhubeka nokuxhasa isiseko sakhe soxolo kwaye uzakuhlala eyinxalenye yeqela labadala baseburhulumenteni abakhankasela uxolo kunye namalungelo oluntu.
mt0: <pad> Except for his resignation, Tutu said he will continue to support his peace foundation and will remain part of the government's senior officials who campaign for peace and human rights.</s>

en: But Tutu says he will no longer give interviews and, as he put it, will mostly "shut up."
xho: Kodwa uTutu uthi akasayi kuphinda enze udliwano-ndlebe kwaye, njengoko eyibeka, "uvale umlomo."
mt0: <pad> But Tutu says he will not be interviewed again and, as he puts it, "closed the mouth."</s>

en: I have been part of our struggle for freedom and democracy, and I am part of the celebration that we did succeed, he said.
xho: “Ndibe yinxalenye yomzabalazo wethu wenkululeko nedemokhrasi, kwaye ndiyinxalenye yombhiyozo wokuba siye saphumelela,” utshilo.
mt0: <pad> "I've been part of our struggle for freedom and democracy, and I'm part of the celebration that we have succeeded," he said.</s>

en: I have been part of the post apartheid dispensation and long for us to do infinitely better.
xho: “Ndibe yinxalenye yolawulo localucalulo kwaye ndilangazelela ukuba senze ngcono kakhulu.
mt0: <pad> "I've been part of the electoral management and I want to do better."</s>

en: Many say his voice will be missed.
xho: Abaninzi bathi ilizwi lakhe liza kukhunjulwa.
mt0: <pad> Many people say his voice will be missed.</s>

en: Around 500 people including students, staff members and others from surrounding areas attended the event, which was held at the schools premises in Chigumula area.
